China Henan Polytechnic University China Electrocatalytic reduction is an effective method to remove harmful gas NO. In the process of reduction, NH3, one of the most important chemical raw materials in industrial production, can also be produced. However, large-scale practical application of NO electrocatalytic reduction is still a challenge, and to find the efficient, low-cost and stable catalysts is a problem that needs to be solved at present. By use of density functional theory calculation, we systematically studied that the potential of FeS2 (100) containing S vacancy (S-vacancy FeS2) as catalyst for NO electrocatalytic reduction. Our results revealed that NO can be chemisorbed stably at the S vacancy of FeS2 (100) surface and consequent reduction of NO molecular can generate NH3 and H2O. The S-vacancy FeS2 as catalyst has an excellent electrocatalytic activity of NO under ambient conditions. More interestingly, when the O atom of NO molecule is loaded in the S vacancy and side-on is adsorbed, all the steps in the reduction process are exothermic reactions. Our work provides a deep understanding for the search of efficient and low-cost NO reduction catalysts. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords FeS2 NO electrocatalytic reduction First principles calculation 1 Introduction As a pollutant mainly emitted by automobiles and industry, Nitric oxide (NO) is easily oxidized into highly corrosive and toxic Carbon dioxide (CO2) in the air, causing pollution to soil and atmosphere. At the same time, it may cause acid rain, causing great harm to the environment and human health [1–5]. As a result, it is necessary to find effective ways to reduce NO in the atmosphere as soon as possible. In recent years, one of the most popular methods is the electrocatalytic reduction of NO to NH3 and H2O molecules, and NH3 is one of the most important raw materials in industrial production. At present, N2 reduction reaction (NRR) is an effective green ammonia synthesis method, and other researchers have also done a lot of research on this [6–13]. For example, Huang and his coworkers [6] have studied that a series of 3d, 4d and 5d transition metals anchored onto extended Pc monolayer as NRR catalysts through first-principles calculations, and it is also indicated that the hybrid reaction pathway have been widely considered and searched systematically, which is the unique point of this work. Xu et al. [7] studied a variety of metal atoms on borophene as single atom catalysts for ammonia synthesis, and found that Mo and Mn anchors not only had small limiting potential, but also could effectively inhibit hydrogen evolution reactions (HER). Wang and Yang [10] revealed the potential mechanism of a class of two-dimensional TM@g-C4N3 monolayer electrocatalysts for NRR, and V@g-C4N3 was found to be a promising NRR electrocatalyst. Actually, electrocatalytic reduction of NO is similar to that of N2, since there are few studies on NOER, other researchers have applied the inspiration and results of NRR to NOER [14–21]. For instance, Mou et al. [15] studied a Ni2P nanosheet array on carbon paper as an effective NOER catalyst toward the highly catalytic activity of NO to NH3. Li et al. [18] reveal that MnO2 with oxygen vacancies nanowire array on Ti mesh as a high active and stable catalyst for NOER. Greeley et al. [19,20] used density functional theory (DFT) to calculate the NOER process on Pt (100) surface, and described in detail the reduction mechanism of different products. Liang et al. [21] studied the CoP nanowire as an efficient hydroprocessing catalyst for electrochemically converting NO to NH3, and result shown that the catalytic effect was excellent, and the faradaic efficiency is 88.3% and NH3 yield is 47.22 μmol h−1 cm−2. NOER not only solves the problem that NO harms the environment to a certain extent, but also provides an idea for the industrial synthesis of NH3 [22,23]. Nevertheless, it is urgent to find a catalyst with low price, high catalytic activity and high efficiency [24–28]. Two-dimensional (2D) materials have attracted much attention because of their excellent physical, chemical, electronic and optical properties, and have potential application prospects in many fields. The research on 2D materials has very important theoretical and practical significance [18,29-38]. In addition to graphene, other 2D materials such as transition metal (TM) sulfides have also been prepared [39–43], greatly expanding the properties and applications of 2D materials. Transition metal sulfide is a layered material with strong in-plane bonding and very weak out of plane interaction, which can be stripped into two-dimensional layers with a single atom thickness. For example, Esrafili et al. [44] used DFT to study the NO reduction of Al doped MoS2, and the results showed that the reduction of single NO molecule needed to overcome a large energy barrier, while the product N2O was easily generated when two NO molecules were co-adsorbed. Li et al. [45] studied the nitrogen reduction reaction on the edge of 2D transition metal disulfides based on DFT, and the results showed that VS2 had good catalytic activity and selectivity in several materials studied, Liu et al. [46] studied the HER on four different surfaces of FeS2 under different conditions by DFT calculation. Due to its rich resources, low cost and non-toxic characteristics, FeS2 has attracted wide attention and been applied in many fields. For example, FeS2 can be made into magnetic materials [47,48] and photovoltaic materials [49], FeS2 plays an important role in electrochemical systems with high energy density drainage and can be used as cathode material for batteries [50]. FeS2 can also be used in the catalytic field for nitrogen reduction reaction [51,52], hydrodeoxidation [53], hydrodesulfurization [54], water cracking reaction [55] and so on. However, the low efficiency hinders the large-scale application of FeS2. Therefore, the effects of defects and doping on its properties have been studied [56–61] Ray et al. [62] made a detailed and systematic study of S vacancy in FeS2 by using DFT, taking into account not only single vacancy but also various forms of vacancy clusters. In this work, we tried to study the influence of S vacancy defect on its electronic structure and performance. The adsorption and electrocatalytic reduction of NO on S-vacancy FeS2 were studied by first principles calculation. The results show that the adsorption of NO can be activated to a certain extent, and the limiting potential in the reduction reaction path is very small, even we can find the path where all steps are exothermic. 2 Computational details In this work, the spin density functional theory is implemented by using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). Projection enhanced wave (PAW) method is used to describe the interaction between ions and electrons. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew-Burke Enzerhor (PBE) functional is used to describe the exchange correlation. A 2 × 2 × 1 FeS2 supercell with S vacancy containing 16 Fe atoms and 31 S atoms was used for calculation. The cutoff energy was set 400 eV. The vacuum layer was set 12 Å to avoid periodic repetition effects. The Brillouin zone was sampled using a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point grid mesh centered for geometry optimization, while 5 × 5 × 1 k-point grid for electronic structure. All structures were relaxed by using energy convergence criteria of 1.0 × 10 −5 eV/atom, while a self-consistence-field (SCF) convergence criteria to 1.0 × 10 −7 eV/atom, and force convergence criteria of 0.03 eV/Å. To evaluate the stability of S-vacancy FeS2, the formation energy (E form) has been calculated by the Eq. (1): (1) E f o r m = E t o t a l − E p r i s t i n e + E S Where E total, E pristine are energy of FeS2 surface with and without S-vacancy, E S is the energy of a single S atom. The adsorption energy (E ads) was calculated following the Eq. (2): (2) E a d s = E t o t a l − E s u r f a c e − E a d s o r b a t e s Where the E total, E surface and E adsorbates are energy of S-vacancy FeS2 and adsorbates, S-vacancy FeS2, adsorbates, respectively. The reaction free energy (∆G) of every step reaction was calculated by modify the zero-point energy and entropy of DFT. The calculation formula follows Eq. (3): (3) Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E − T Δ S ΔE is obtained from DFT calculations, ∆ZPE is zero-point energy, T is 298.15 K and ∆S is entropy change. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Geometric structure of catalyst model In this work, the FeS2 (100) surface with S-vacancy is selected and the geometric structure is shown in Fig. 1 (a). It consists of two atomic layers and contains a total of 16 Fe atoms and 31 S atoms. The optimized S-vacancy FeS2 geometric structure in Fig. 1(a) has no obvious distortion, indicating that the S-vacancy can exist stably. The stability of catalyst is a necessary condition for the catalytic process. Our calculated formation energy (E form) of S-vacancy is 1.74 eV, which is consistent with previous reports. In order to better study the adsorption and subsequent reduction process of NO, we first studied the geometric structure and electronic properties of FeS2 containing S vacancy (S-vacancy FeS2). Fig. 1(b) shows the DOS of the pristine FeS2 and S-vacancy FeS2. The DOS of pristine FeS2 shows that pristine FeS2 is semiconducting with a band gap of 0.425 eV. It's evident that the existence of S vacancy changes the electronic structure of the pristine FeS2 and the band gap is obviously reduced from 0.425 to 0.149 eV, thus leading to a significant increase in the electrical conductivity of S-vacancy FeS2. In addition, PDOS and charge density of pristine and S-vacancy FeS2 are shown in Fig. S1 and Fig. S2, respectively (support materials). From the PDOS of pristine FeS2 in Fig. S1 (support material), it can be seen that Fe and S elements have the same peak shape trend, indicating interaction between the two elements. However, system occurred spin polarization because of existence of S vacancy. Furthermore, hybridization of Fe-3d orbital and S-2p orbital is more obvious, and an energy level appears near Fermi-level to receive electrons, which is conductive to charge transfer between gas molecules and the substrate. 3.2 Adsorption of NO on S-vacancy FeS2 In this work, we mainly studied the adsorption of NO at the S vacancy and the subsequent reduction reaction [63,64]. When NO is adsorbed with a side-on pattern, N atom of NO loaded in the S vacancy, it is referred to as S1 structure for short, but S2 structure for O atom loaded. NO is adsorbed in an end-on pattern, the N atom loaded in vacancy is E1 structure, and the O atom loaded in vacancy is E2 structure. Table S1 in the support material lists the adsorption energy of NO at multiple possible adsorption sites and the change of N-O bond length. Fig. 2 lists the four most stable geometric structures, and (a-d) are S1, E1, S2 and E2 respectively. It can be seen from Table 1 that the adsorption energy (E ads) of NO at the S vacancy ranges from -1.895 to -2.342 eV, indicating that there is a strong chemical adsorption between NO and the surface, and S-vacancy FeS2 is sensitive to NO gas and NO adsorption is an exothermic process [65]. According to Table 1 and Fig. 2, it can be known that NO is more inclined to be loaded with N atoms at the S vacancy. The N-O bond length of the free NO gas is 1.169 Å [66], and after adsorption, the bond length is elongated by about 0.064 to 0.121 Å, indicating that NO is activated to different degrees, which is conducive to the subsequent reduction steps. In order to further study the electron interaction between NO molecule and FeS2 (100) surface with S vacancy, we drawn the charge differential density (CDD) in Fig. 2(e-h). The charge transfer is positive indicating that NO molecule receives electrons. It can be clearly seen that the charge accumulation mainly occurs on the NO molecule for all the system, while the charge consumption mainly concentrates on the Fe atom near the NO molecule. By Bader charge analysis, the charges transferred from catalyst surface to NO in S1, E1, S2 and E2 structures are 0.711, 0.576, 0.573 and 0.601 e, respectively. The unfilled 2π* orbitals of NO accept electrons resulting in an increase in N-O bond length [67,68]. Such advantageous orbital interactions can also be understood from the partial density of state (PDOS) and the projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) in Fig. 3 , which the 3d orbital of Fe atom are hybridization with the 2π* orbital of NO near the Fermi-level. In order to learn deeply how NO is activated, we studied the interaction between NO and FeS2 (100) surface with S vacancy by drawn the PDOS and the pCOHP. COHP analysis is widely used to describe the bonding characteristics of atomic interactions [69]. In general, a COHP value of 0 indicates a non-bonding state, the positive and negative values indicate bonding and antibonding states, respectively. From COHP analysis, it can be seen that the bond contribution of N-O mainly comes from 5σ and 2π* orbitals, which correspond to 2p orbitals in DOS. In addition, the presence of a single electron in the 2π* orbital near the Fermi level indicates that it is paramagnetic. It can be seen from Table 1 that the adsorption capacity of NO at the S vacancy is strong, which may be mainly related to their orbitals. The unoccupied orbital of S-vacancy FeS2 (100) receives electrons from the 5σ orbital of NO molecule, and the occupied orbital also donates electrons from the 2π* orbital of NO molecule. It is clearly seen that all valence states (below Fermi-level) not only have the bonding states but also the antibonding states. This is caused by the valence difference and mixing of the s and p molecular orbitals in NO molecule [70,71]. 3.3 NO reduction reaction mechanism on S-vacancy FeS2 As shown in scheme 1 , the electrocatalytic reduction process of NO on S-vacancy FeS2 was studied, and the adsorbed NO molecule could be reduced to NH3 through a 5 electron pathway, (NO (g) + 5H+ + 5e− = NH3 (g) + H2O (l)) [66,72]. The adsorbed NO molecule is hydrogenated by proton-electron (H+/e−) interaction. There are two possible reaction pathways for hydrogenation reduction for *NO. One is that the N atom of *NO molecule is hydrogenated to form the intermediate of HNO*, the other is that the O atom of *NO molecule is hydrogenated to form the intermediate of *NOH [73]. There are two different intermediates formed in each step of hydrogenation reaction. We evaluated the NO electronic reduction (NOER) performance of S-vacancy FeS2 electric catalyst by studying the minimum energy structure of each step and analyzing different reaction pathways. Fig. 4 shows the free energy barrier diagram of each step of hydrogenation of the four structures, and Fig. 5 lists the optimized structure of each intermediate in the optimized pathway of each structure. For S1 structure (Fig. 4(a)), N atom in NO* was loaded in the S vacancy, O atoms prefer to form *NOH intermediates by occasional hydrogenation of electrons and protons[74,75] by adsorption according the calculation results. The ∆G for the formation of HNO* in the first hydrogenation of S1 is 0.32 eV, while the ∆G for the formation of NOH is 0.10 eV. As is shown in Fig. 4 (a), further hydrogenation of NOH* intermediate leads to two possible reaction pathways. One is the hydrogenation of N atom to form *HNOH intermediates, with ∆G decreased by 1.69 eV. In the other case, the O atom continues to hydrogenate to produce H2O for release, leaving the *N species, with the ∆G downhill for 1.48 eV. Therefore, we think that *HNOH intermediate is more easily formed in the first step of hydrogenation. Similarly, *HNOH is easily hydrogenated to form HN*+*H2O. For S1 structure, the N and O atoms are alternately hydrogenated until H2O is produced and released, leaving the *NH species, which continues to be hydrogenated until NH3 is produced and released. In this pathway, the ∆G of each intermediate are -0.59 (*NH+H2O), 0.16 (*NH2), and -0.66 (*NH3) eV, respectively. Therefore, the fourth hydrogenation step is the potential determining step (PDS) with maximum ∆G uphill for 0.16 eV during this process. For E1 structure (Fig. 4(b)), the distal O atom are hydrogenated until H2O release and rest *N continues to hydrogenate to produce *NH3. In whole reduction pathway, the ∆G of each intermediate are -0.06 (*NOH), -1.33 (*N+H2O), -0.72 (*NH), 0.04 (*NH2) and -0.55 (*NH3) eV, respectively. Except that the fourth step (for the formation of *NH2) is endothermic reaction, the hydrogenation steps are exothermic reactions. Consequently, as with S1 structure, the fourth step hydrogenation is the PDS, and the limiting potential is 0.04 eV. For S2 and E2 structure, N is still closer to the S vacancy in NO* after optimization, indicating that N atom prefers to be loaded in the S vacancy. It can be seen from the calculation results that the ∆G for the formation of HNO* in the first hydrogenation of S2 and E2 is -0.21 and -0.02 eV, respectively, while the ∆G for the formation of NOH is 0.20 and -0.38 eV, respectively. As a result, hydrogenation tends to form HNO* species on N atom in the first step for S2 structure, while *NOH species for E2 structure. For S2 structure (Fig. 4(c)), the first step of hydrogenation to form *NOH needs to overcome barrier for 0.20 eV, so we focus on the situation of HNO* formation. In the same way, and the second step of hydrogenation may form two different intermediates HNOH* (0.29 eV) and H2NO* (-0.67 eV). With further hydrogenation, the proton-electron pair is still more likely to attack the N atom of H2NO* to form H3NO*(-1.15 eV). The whole reaction process follows the hydrogenation of N atom until NH3 is produced, leaving O species to continue to hydrogenate until H2O is formed. As can be seen from Fig. 4(c), the values for each of the intermediate formation are -0.21 (HNO*), -0.69 (H2NO*), -1.15 (H3NO*), -0.20 (*OH) and -0.51 (*H2O) eV, respectively, each step of hydrogenation process is exothermic reaction and can be formed spontaneously. It can be seen from the ∆G values calculated at each step that the fourth hydrogenation process, namely, the generation of intermediate *OH, has the smallest falling energy, which is the PDS. However, for the E2 structure (Fig. 4(d)), the first step of hydrogenation is also possible to produce two different intermediates, namely, HNO*(-0.02 eV) and *NOH (-0.32 eV). Since both paths are exothermic reactions and relatively easy to occur, we consider two different paths here. We first studied *NOH pathway (black line). The ∆G of rest each intermediate are -1.13 (*N+H2O*), -0.68 (*NH), 0.84 (*NH2) and -1.24 (*NH3) eV, respectively. In the whole reduction process, ∆G increase by 0.84 eV when the fourth hydrogenation, and the limiting potential is 0.84 eV. Since the rate-limiting potential in the *NOH path is higher and the formation of HNO* is also an exothermic process, we further studied the HNO path. In the same way, we also listed the ∆G diagram of the HNO* path (blue line) in Fig. 4(d). It can be seen that the 0.03 eV energy barrier needs to be overcome only when the second step hydrogenation to form H2NO*. It can be seen from the above that the presence of O atom can effectively promote the hydrogenation reduction of NO. In addition, compared with the pathway of dehydration first, then deamination, the pathway of deamination first, then dehydration is more advantageous in terms of energy. This calculation is consistent with that of other researchers [52,66,76-79]. In a word, the presence of S vacancy increases the conductivity of FeS2 (100) surface. NO adsorption is a strong chemisorption and more electron transfer occurs, which lays the foundation for the subsequent NO electroreduction reaction. By comparing the energy of four structures reduction reaction pathways, we can clearly see that S-vacancy FeS2 has an excellent electrocatalytic reduction activity for NO, and when NO is adsorbed with side-on pattern and O is loaded in S vacancy, each step in the reaction process is exothermic reaction. Therefore, we believe that the presence of S vacancy can effectively promote the NO reduction activity of FeS2 catalyst with a lower limiting potential. 4 Conclusion To summarize, by means of first principles calculations, we studied that NO electrocatalytic reduction performance of FeS2 (100) surface with S vacancy. Our results revealed that NO can be chemisorbed stably at the S vacancy of FeS2 (100) surface and the S-vacancy FeS2 catalyst exhibits prominent catalytic activity for the NO electrocatalytic reduction. Furthermore, when the O atom of NO molecule is loaded in the S vacancy and adsorbed in side-on pattern, all the processes are exothermic reactions. This work may provide a theoretical basis for promoting the search of non-noble metal catalysts for the electrocatalytic reduction of NO. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic reduction is an effective method to remove harmful gas NO. In the process of reduction, NH3, one of the most important chemical raw materials in industrial production, can also be produced. However, large-scale practical application of NO electrocatalytic reduction is still a challenge, and to find the efficient, low-cost and stable catalysts is a problem that needs to be solved at present. By use of density functional theory calculation, we systematically studied that the potential of FeS2 (100) containing S vacancy (S-vacancy FeS2) as catalyst for NO electrocatalytic reduction. Our results revealed that NO can be chemisorbed stably at the S vacancy of FeS2 (100) surface and consequent reduction of NO molecular can generate NH3 and H2O. The S-vacancy FeS2 as catalyst has an excellent electrocatalytic activity of NO under ambient conditions. More interestingly, when the O atom of NO molecule is loaded in the S vacancy and side-on is adsorbed, all the steps in the reduction process are exothermic reactions. Our work provides a deep understanding for the search of efficient and low-cost NO reduction catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Design of S-vacancy FeS2 as an electrocatalyst for NO reduction reaction: A DFT study
